questions.text: An elderly patient dies due to a cancer and his cells in the cancer affected area were examined. Ultra structurally, the most prominent features found are the loss of mitochondrial cristae and ruptured outer mitochondrial membrane. Which of the following best can be the pattern of cell death here?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ferroptosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Necrosis is a form of cell death characterized by uncontrolled cell lysis , often resulting in inflammation.
  • • Option A. Necrosis
  • • cell death
  • • uncontrolled cell lysis
  • • inflammation.
  • • Option B. Necroptosis is a type of programmed necrosis that is dependent on receptor-interacting protein kinases and often associated with inflammation.
  • • Option B. Necroptosis
  • • programmed necrosis
  • • receptor-interacting protein kinases
  • • Option D. Pyroptosis is an inflammatory form of programmed cell death associated with the activation of caspase-1 and often seen in immune cells.
  • • Option D. Pyroptosis
  • • inflammatory form of programmed cell death
  • • activation of caspase-1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ferroptosis is a regulated cell death pathway marked by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation , resulting in distinctive ultrastructural changes such as loss of mitochondrial cristae and rupture of the outer mitochondrial membrane , commonly associated with cancer, neurodegeneration, and stroke .
  • ➤ Ferroptosis
  • ➤ regulated cell death pathway marked by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation
  • ➤ loss of mitochondrial cristae and rupture of the outer mitochondrial membrane
  • ➤ cancer, neurodegeneration, and stroke

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding reversible cell injury, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix

options.label: C
options.text: Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum

questions.correct_answer: A. Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Formation of amorphous densities in the mitochondrial matrix is typically associated with irreversible cell injury rather than reversible cell injury. This change indicates severe damage to the mitochondria, often due to sustained injury that compromises mitochondrial function beyond the cell's ability to recover.
  • • Other Options Explained:
  • • Other Options Explained:
  • • Option B. Diminished generation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) : This is characteristic of reversible cell injury. It occurs due to temporary impairment of mitochondrial function, which can recover if the injurious stimulus is removed. Option C. Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane : Blebbing is a response to reversible cell injury. It involves changes in the cytoskeleton and plasma membrane, which can be restored once the injury ceases. Option D. Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum : This change can occur during reversible cell injury and reflects a temporary disruption in protein synthesis. If the injury is mild and transient, normal ribosomal function can resume.
  • • Option B. Diminished generation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) : This is characteristic of reversible cell injury. It occurs due to temporary impairment of mitochondrial function, which can recover if the injurious stimulus is removed.
  • • Option B. Diminished generation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)
  • • Option C. Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane : Blebbing is a response to reversible cell injury. It involves changes in the cytoskeleton and plasma membrane, which can be restored once the injury ceases.
  • • Option C. Formation of blebs in the plasma membrane
  • • Option D. Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum : This change can occur during reversible cell injury and reflects a temporary disruption in protein synthesis. If the injury is mild and transient, normal ribosomal function can resume.
  • • Option D. Detachment of ribosomes from the granular endoplasmic reticulum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amorphous densities in mitochondria are a hallmark of irreversible injury, while diminished ATP production, membrane blebbing, and ribosome detachment are associated with reversible cell injury

questions.text: Which of the following is a form of programmed cell death that is dependent on the formation of autophagosomes and leads to the degradation of cellular components?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Autophagy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Necroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that resembles necrosis , characterized by cell swelling and membrane rupture, typically involving death receptors like TNFR1 but is not associated with autophagosomes.
  • • Option A. Necroptosis
  • • resembles necrosis
  • • cell swelling and membrane rupture,
  • • TNFR1
  • • Option B. Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death involving cell shrinkage, DNA fragmentation, and the formation of apoptotic bodies, without the formation of autophagosomes .
  • • Option B. Apoptosis
  • • programmed cell death
  • • cell shrinkage, DNA fragmentation, and the formation of apoptotic bodies, without the formation of autophagosomes
  • • Option C. Pyroptosis is an inflammatory form of programmed cell death that occurs upon activation of inflammasomes and leads to cell lysis and inflammation, not primarily involving autophagosomes.
  • • Option C. Pyroptosis
  • • inflammatory form of programmed cell death
  • • not primarily involving autophagosomes.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autophagy is a form of programmed cell death characterized by the formation of autophagosomes that engulf and degrade cellular components in response to cellular stress.
  • ➤ Autophagy
  • ➤ programmed cell death
  • ➤ formation of autophagosomes
  • ➤ engulf and degrade cellular components
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th / 48
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th / 48

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of heavy smoking complains of chronic cough. On chest radiograph, he has a suspicious lesion on the right upper lobe. Bronchoscopy and biopsy reveals that the mass has bronchial mucosa displays squamous metaplasia. What is the most likely outcome of this lesion if the said individual stops smoking?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reversion to normal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Atrophy refers to the shrinkage in the size of the cell by loss of cell substance . When it comes to bronchial epithelium, atrophy is less common as a direct result of cessation of smoking.
  • • Option A. Atrophy
  • • shrinkage in the size of the cell
  • • loss of cell substance
  • • bronchial epithelium, atrophy is less common
  • • Option B. Malignant transformation is the process by which cells acquire the abilities to form a malignancy or cancer. Squamous metaplasia can be a precursor to squamous cell carcinoma ; however, it is a potentially reversible process, and the risk of malignant transformation decreases if the irritating stimulus , in this case, smoking, is removed .
  • • Option B. Malignant transformation
  • • cells acquire the abilities to form a malignancy or cancer.
  • • precursor to squamous cell carcinoma
  • • reversible process,
  • • risk of malignant transformation decreases
  • • irritating stimulus
  • • smoking, is removed
  • • Option C. Necrosis and scarring would occur as a result of cell death and tissue damage. This is more typical of an end-stage process of persistent damage , rather than a result of the cessation of smoking.
  • • Option C. Necrosis and scarring
  • • result of cell death and tissue damage.
  • • end-stage process of persistent damage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Squamous metaplasia in the bronchial epithelium due to chronic irritation from smoking is a reversible process, and upon cessation of smoking , the epithelium has the potential to revert to its normal state.
  • ➤ Squamous metaplasia
  • ➤ bronchial epithelium
  • ➤ smoking is a reversible process,
  • ➤ cessation of smoking
  • ➤ revert to its normal state.
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th / 61
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th / 61

questions.text: Physiological hyperplasia and hypertrophy are seen simultaneously in? Uterus in pregnancy Skeletal muscle in athletes Breast at puberty Left ventricle of heart in hypertensive patients
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both 1 and 3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option 1 : During pregnancy, the uterus undergoes both hyperplasia (increased number of cells) and hypertrophy (increase in the size of existing cells) as a physiological response to accommodate and support the developing fetus . This dual increase in size and number of cells allows the uterus to significantly expand during pregnancy .
  • • Option 1
  • • pregnancy,
  • • both hyperplasia (increased number of cells) and hypertrophy (increase in the size of existing cells)
  • • accommodate and support the developing fetus
  • • allows the uterus
  • • expand during pregnancy
  • • Option 2: Athletes who undergo rigorous training often experience skeletal muscle hypertrophy , which is the increase in the size of muscle cells , but not typically hyperplasia , which would be an increase in the number of muscle cells. Muscle growth in athletes is usually attributed to hypertrophy from repetitive use and strain .
  • • Option 2:
  • • experience skeletal muscle hypertrophy
  • • increase in the size of muscle cells
  • • not typically hyperplasia
  • • Muscle growth
  • • hypertrophy from repetitive use and strain
  • • Option 3: During puberty , the female breast displays both hyperplasia , with the proliferation of glandular epithelium, and hypertrophy , with the enlargement of the glandular epithelial cells . This dual change is stimulated by hormonal influences and is a natural part of sexual maturation .
  • • Option 3:
  • • During puberty
  • • both hyperplasia
  • • proliferation of glandular epithelium,
  • • hypertrophy
  • • enlargement of the glandular epithelial cells
  • • by hormonal influences
  • • sexual maturation
  • • Option 4: In hypertensive patients , the left ventricle may undergo hypertrophy due to increased resistance that the heart has to pump against . This is not a physiological but rather a pathological response and typically does not involve hyperplasia , which would be characterized by an increased number of cardiac muscle cells.
  • • Option 4:
  • • In hypertensive patients
  • • left ventricle
  • • hypertrophy due to increased resistance
  • • pump against
  • • pathological response
  • • does not involve hyperplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the uterus during pregnancy and the breast at puberty , physiological changes involve both hyperplasia ( increase in the number of cells) and hypertrophy (increase in the size of cells). These changes are driven by hormonal influences that are part of natural growth and development processes .
  • ➤ In the uterus during pregnancy
  • ➤ the breast at puberty
  • ➤ hyperplasia (
  • ➤ hypertrophy
  • ➤ driven by hormonal influences
  • ➤ natural growth and development processes

questions.text: A 36-year-old female Rajvanti underwent a cervical biopsy at AIIMS after a suspicious Pap smear report. On histopathologic examination, it was observed that normal columnar endocervical epithelium was replaced with squamous epithelium in places. Which cellular adaptation does this describe?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Metaplasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells in an organ or tissue , usually resulting in an increased volume of the tissue or organ . This process is often stimulated by hormonal or compensatory cellular mechanisms in response to a demand or injury .
  • • Option A.
  • • Hyperplasia
  • • increase in the number of cells
  • • organ or tissue
  • • an increased volume of the tissue or organ
  • • stimulated by hormonal or compensatory
  • • demand or injury
  • • Option B. Hypertrophy refers to an increase in the size of cells, which consequently increases the size of the organ . It does not involve an increase in the number of cells. This is typically seen in muscles due to increased workload, as in the heart’s response to hypertension.
  • • Option B.
  • • Hypertrophy
  • • an increase in the size of cells,
  • • increases the size of the organ
  • • seen
  • • muscles due to increased workload,
  • • Option D. Dysplasia is an abnormal growth or development of cells and is often considered a precancerous state. It involves changes in size, shape, and organization of mature cells , and it is not a physiological but a pathological process.
  • • Option D.
  • • Dysplasia
  • • abnormal growth or development of cells
  • • precancerous state.
  • • changes in size, shape, and organization of mature cells
  • • pathological process.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metaplasia often occurs as a result of chronic irritation and represents a reversible change in cell type , as is evident in the case of Rajvanti’s cervical biopsy findings.
  • ➤ Metaplasia
  • ➤ chronic irritation and represents a reversible change in cell type
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed PG: 59,60
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed PG: 59,60

questions.text: A smoker was found to have replacement of ciliated columnar epithelium in his respiratory tract to squamous epithelium. Which of the following is the mechanism involved in the observed change?

options.label: A
options.text: Reprogramming of local tissue stem cells

options.label: C
options.text: Growth factor driven proliferation of mature cells

questions.correct_answer: A. Reprogramming of local tissue stem cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reprogramming of local tissue stem cells

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Decreased protein synthesis is associated with atrophy, where cells reduce in size due to a loss of cell substance . In tissues, this can occur from disuse, decreased blood supply, malnutrition, or denervation .
  • • Option B. Decreased protein synthesis
  • • atrophy,
  • • cells reduce in size
  • • loss of cell substance
  • • disuse, decreased blood supply, malnutrition, or denervation
  • • Option C. Growth factor-driven proliferation refers to the increase in cell number due to stimulation by growth factors. This is the underlying mechanism of hyperplasia, a condition characterized by an increased number of cells in a tissue or organ, often as a response to a stimulus .
  • • Option C. Growth factor-driven proliferation refers to the increase in cell
  • • mechanism of hyperplasia,
  • • increased number of cells in a tissue or organ,
  • • response to a stimulus
  • • Option D. Increased cellular protein production is typically observed in hypertrophy , where cells increase in size. This often occurs in response to increased demand or hormonal stimulation , such as in muscle cells after extensive exercise or in the myocardium in response to hypertension .
  • • Option D. Increased cellular protein production
  • • hypertrophy
  • • increased demand or hormonal stimulation
  • • muscle cells after extensive exercise
  • • myocardium in response to hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct mechanism involved in the change from ciliated columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of a smoker is, reprogramming of local tissue stem cells . Metaplasia occurs due to the reprogramming of stem cells in the tissue to produce a cell type better suited to withstand the stress , in this case, the chronic irritation from smoking .
  • ➤ correct mechanism involved
  • ➤ ciliated columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of a smoker
  • ➤ reprogramming of local tissue stem cells
  • ➤ better suited to withstand the stress

questions.text: Which of these are premalignant conditions: Anaplasia Metaplasia Hamartoma Dysplasia
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option 1. Anaplasia: This refers to a lack of differentiation within cells and is characteristic of malignant tumors , where cells lose the morphological features of mature cells and their organization . Anaplastic cells often show variations in size and shape , a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio , and prominent nucleoli .
  • • Option 1. Anaplasia:
  • • lack of differentiation within cells
  • • characteristic of malignant tumors
  • • cells lose
  • • morphological features of mature cells
  • • their organization
  • • variations in size and shape
  • • nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio
  • • prominent nucleoli
  • • Option 2. Metaplasia: This is a process whereby one differentiated cell type is replaced by another cell type , which can occur due to chronic irritation or inflammation . While metaplasia is not cancer, it can sometimes progress to dysplasia and then to cancer.
  • • Option 2. Metaplasia:
  • • one differentiated cell type is replaced by another cell type
  • • due to chronic irritation or inflammation
  • • progress to dysplasia and then to cancer.
  • • Option 3. Hamartoma: Although traditionally considered benign, hamartomas are now increasingly recognized as having the potential to become malignant, particularly if they are not monitored or managed appropriately.
  • • Option 3. Hamartoma:
  • • now increasingly recognized
  • • potential to become malignant,
  • • Option 4. Dysplasia: Dysplasia is indeed a precancerous condition characterized by the abnormal development and growth of cells within tissues . It can lead to cellular abnormalities and is often seen in epithelial tissue during screening for cancers, such as a Pap smear for cervical cancer .
  • • Option 4. Dysplasia:
  • • precancerous condition characterized by the abnormal development and growth of cells within tissues
  • • cellular abnormalities
  • • epithelial tissue
  • • Pap smear for cervical cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anaplasia, metaplasia, and dysplasia are conditions with cells that have an increased risk of malignancy . While a hamartoma is a benign tumor-like malformation , it's not typically classified as a premalignant condition, although some literature suggests it may have malignant potential .
  • ➤ Anaplasia, metaplasia, and dysplasia
  • ➤ increased risk of malignancy
  • ➤ hamartoma is a benign tumor-like malformation
  • ➤ it may have malignant potential
  • ➤ Ref Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10th ed

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffers a heart attack and expires. Examination of his cardiac tissue reveals the finding as shown in the image. The pigment in the image represents which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Wear and tear pigment

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Fat deposits: Fat deposits in the heart could suggest a lipid disorder or myocardial steatosis but typically appear as clear vacuoles within the cells , not as the dark, granular pigment seen in the image.
  • • Option B. Fat deposits:
  • • lipid disorder or myocardial steatosis
  • • clear vacuoles within the cells
  • • Option C. Blood pigment : Hemosiderin , the storage form of iron, can accumulate in tissues following hemorrhage or excessive iron intake , presenting as a golden-yellow to brown pigment, which is different in appearance from the pigment seen here.
  • • Option C. Blood pigment
  • • Hemosiderin
  • • accumulate in tissues
  • • hemorrhage or excessive iron intake
  • • Option D. Form of calcification: Calcification in tissues appears as basophilic (blue-purple) stippling or clumps within tissues on histology, which does not match the pigment observed in the image.
  • • Option D. Form of calcification:
  • • basophilic (blue-purple) stippling or clumps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipofuscin, the pigment seen in the cardiac tissue of the patient who suffered a heart attack, is indicative of free radical damage and is not harmful to cell function .

questions.text: Regarding dystrophic calcification, which of the following statements is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: It may be caused by multiple myeloma

options.label: D
options.text: Calcium deposition occurs in dead tissues

questions.correct_answer: D. Calcium deposition occurs in dead tissues
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Calcium deposition occurs in dead tissues

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. It may be caused by multiple myeloma : Multiple myeloma itself does not cause dystrophic calcification . However, it can lead to systemic changes that result in pathologic calcifications . Dystrophic calcification is specifically associated with local tissue damage and necrosis , not directly with plasma cell disorders like multiple myeloma.
  • • Option A.
  • • It may be caused by multiple myeloma
  • • Multiple myeloma
  • • does not
  • • dystrophic calcification
  • • systemic changes
  • • pathologic calcifications
  • • Dystrophic calcification
  • • local tissue damage and necrosis
  • • Option B. It never causes organ dysfunction: This statement is incorrect. While dystrophic calcification occurs in non-viable tissues , it can interfere with organ function depending on the size and location of the calcifications.
  • • Option B. It never causes organ dysfunction:
  • • dystrophic calcification
  • • non-viable tissues
  • • interfere
  • • organ function depending on the size and location of the calcifications.
  • • Option C. It is associated with hypercalcaemia : Dystrophic calcification can occur despite normal serum levels of calcium . It is not typically associated with hypercalcemia, which is more commonly linked with metastatic calcification .
  • • Option C.
  • • It is associated with hypercalcaemia
  • • Dystrophic calcification
  • • despite
  • • calcium
  • • with metastatic calcification

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dystrophic calcification is the deposition of calcium salts in non-viable or dying tissues and can occur with normal serum calcium levels , often leading to organ dysfunction if extensive .

questions.text: With regard to metaplasia, which of the following statements is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: It is typically an irreversible process

options.label: B
options.text: It preserves mucus secretion in the respiratory tract

options.label: C
options.text: It is the process that occurs in Barrett's esophagus

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: C. It is the process that occurs in Barrett's esophagus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is the process that occurs in Barrett’s esophagus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. It is typically an irreversible process: This is incorrect. Metaplasia is a reversible process , where one adult cell type changes to another to better survive an adverse environment.
  • • Option A. It is typically an irreversible process:
  • • Metaplasia
  • • reversible process
  • • Option B. It preserves mucus secretion in the respiratory tract: Incorrect. Metaplasia often leads to the replacement of columnar epithelium with squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract due to smoking , which does not preserve mucus secretion as the new cell type lacks this function .
  • • Option B. It preserves mucus secretion in the respiratory tract:
  • • Metaplasia
  • • replacement of columnar epithelium with squamous epithelium
  • • due to smoking
  • • does not preserve mucus secretion
  • • new cell type lacks this function
  • • Option D. It can be caused by vitamin B12 deficiency: This is incorrect. While vitamin deficiencies can lead to changes in epithelia , it is vitamin A deficiency that is typically associated with squamous metaplasia , not vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • • Option D.
  • • It can be caused by vitamin B12 deficiency:
  • • vitamin deficiencies
  • • epithelia
  • • vitamin A deficiency
  • • with squamous metaplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • • uniformity and architectural orientation of cells
  • • Option D. It is a feature of mesenchymal cells: Incorrect. Dysplasia is typically a feature of epithelial cells , not mesenchymal cells. Mesenchymal cells can undergo changes that may be equivalent to dysplasia , such as in fibroblastic proliferations, but the term dysplasia is usually used with epithelial pathology .

  • • epithelial cells

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct statement about senescence?

options.label: B
options.text: Aging is associated with increased telomerase activity

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aging is associated with decreased telomerase activity

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Aging is associated with increased telomerase activity: This is generally incorrect for normal somatic cells , as aging does not typically come with increased telomerase activity, which is often associated with immortalized cancer cells.
  • • Option B. Aging is associated with increased telomerase activity: This is generally incorrect for normal somatic cells
  • • Option C. Stem cells have reduced telomerase activity: This statement is generally not true; stem cells and germ cells often have higher levels of telomerase activity, allowing them to maintain telomere length and proliferative capacity.
  • • Option C.
  • • Stem cells have reduced telomerase activity:
  • • This statement is generally not true;
  • • Option D. Associated with increased cell replication: Senescence is actually associated with a decrease or cessation in cell replication due to telomere shortening and the activation of tumor suppressor genes .
  • • Option D.
  • • Associated with increased cell replication:
  • • Senescence
  • • decrease or cessation in cell replication due to telomere shortening
  • • activation of tumor suppressor genes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aging in somatic cells is associated with decreased telomerase activity , which contributes to telomere shortening and the subsequent arrest of cell division , a process known as replicative senescence.
  • ➤ Aging in somatic cells
  • ➤ decreased telomerase activity
  • ➤ telomere shortening and the subsequent arrest of cell division
  • ➤ replicative senescence.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man has a 30-year history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. He has had extensive black discoloration of skin and soft tissue of his right foot, with areas of yellowish exudate, for the past 2 months. Staphylococcus aureus is cultured from this exudate. A below-the-knee amputation is performed. The amputation specimen received in the surgical pathology laboratory is most likely to demonstrate which of the following pathologic abnormalities?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gangrene

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. A neoplasm is a mass lesion.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option C. Vasculitis (with either thrombosis or hemorrhage), would be more likely manifested throughout the body. Coagulopathy is not a feature of diabetes mellitus .
  • • Option C.
  • • Vasculitis (with either thrombosis or hemorrhage),
  • • Coagulopathy is not a feature of diabetes mellitus
  • • Option D. Caseation is a part of granulomatous inflammation. Caseating granulomas are soft, cheesy, and white.
  • • Option D.
  • • granulomatous inflammation.
  • • soft, cheesy, and white.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gangrene, particularly wet gangrene is characterized by black discoloration and exudate in a diabetic patient, and is a consequence of coagulative necrosis coupled with bacterial infection , typically necessitating amputation of the affected area.
  • ➤ Gangrene,
  • ➤ wet gangrene
  • ➤ black discoloration and exudate in a diabetic patient,
  • ➤ coagulative necrosis coupled with bacterial infection
  • ➤ amputation

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the hospital with shortness of breath and fever. A chest x-ray shows evidence of pneumonia, and he is started on antibiotics. Despite treatment, his condition deteriorates, and a bronchoalveolar lavage is performed, which reveals the presence of cells undergoing a type of cell death characterized by swelling, membrane rupture, and the release of damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs). What type of cell death is this most likely to be?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Necroptosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Apoptosis is a form of programmed cell death involving cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, membrane blebbing, and DNA fragmentation , without inflammation or DAMP release.
  • • Option A: Apoptosis
  • • programmed cell death
  • • cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation, membrane blebbing, and DNA fragmentation
  • • Option B: Pyroptosis is a form of inflammatory programmed cell death associated with infection and is characterized by the activation of inflammatory caspases , cell swelling, membrane pore formation, and release of inflammatory cytokines.
  • • Option B: Pyroptosis
  • • inflammatory programmed cell death
  • • infection
  • • inflammatory caspases
  • • cell swelling, membrane pore formation, and release of inflammatory cytokines.
  • • Option C: Autophagy is a process where cells degrade their own components through the lysosomal machinery , typically as a survival mechanism in response to stress, without immediate cell death or DAMP release.
  • • Option C: Autophagy
  • • cells degrade their own components through the lysosomal machinery
  • • without immediate cell death or DAMP release.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Necroptosis is a form of programmed cell death marked by cellular swelling, membrane disruption, and DAMP release, which can be associated with conditions such as COPD and infection-related inflammation.
  • ➤ programmed cell death
  • ➤ cellular swelling, membrane disruption, and DAMP release,
  • ➤ COPD and infection-related inflammation.

questions.text: The lifestyle patterns of healthy persons from 20 to 30 years of age are studied. A subset of these persons has a lifestyle characterized by consumption of a lot of pizza and very little physical exercise. Which of the following tissue changes is most likely to develop in this subset of persons as a consequence of this lifestyle?

options.label: D
options.text: Metaplasia of muscle to adipose tissue

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypertrophy of steatocytes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Fatty change in the liver is due to toxic and metabolic derangements, such as those that occur with malnutrition or alcoholism . Similarly, fatty change in the heart (Option B) is a consequence of toxic or hypoxic events.
  • • Option A.
  • • toxic and metabolic derangements,
  • • malnutrition or alcoholism
  • • (Option B)
  • • Option D . Muscle does not typically undergo metaplasia in response to weight gain . Adipocytes in fascial planes and around the muscle can increase in size. The muscle may atrophy in response to the sedentary lifestyle .
  • • Option D
  • • Muscle does not
  • • metaplasia
  • • weight gain
  • • atrophy in response to the sedentary lifestyle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In adults, hypertrophy of adipocytes, or steatocytes, is the primary tissue change associated with weight gain due to excessive caloric intake and insufficient exercise , as this leads to an increase in fat cell size .
  • ➤ hypertrophy of adipocytes, or steatocytes,
  • ➤ weight gain due to excessive caloric intake and insufficient exercise
  • ➤ increase in fat cell size

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman Yashi gives birth to her first child. She begins breast feeding the infant. She continues breast feeding for almost 6 months with no difficulties and no complications. Which of the following cellular processes that began in the breast during pregnancy allowed her to nurse the infant for this period of time?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lobular hyperplasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Metaplasia is the exchange of the normal epithelium for another in response to chronic irritation.
  • • Option A. Metaplasia
  • • exchange of the normal epithelium
  • • chronic irritation.
  • • Option B. The stroma of the breast consists of connective tissue that provides structural support , but does not have cells that produce milk.
  • • Option B. The stroma of the breast
  • • connective tissue that provides structural support
  • • Option C. Dysplasia in epithelia is a pre-malignant change not part of normal physiologic events . This would be a precursor to breast cancer . Pregnancy is a protective factor against breast cancer.
  • • Option C. Dysplasia in epithelia
  • • pre-malignant change not part of normal physiologic events
  • • precursor to breast cancer
  • • Pregnancy is
  • • protective factor against breast cancer.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lobular hyperplasia that is particularly influenced by progesterone , facilitates lactation postpartum.
  • ➤ Lobular hyperplasia
  • ➤ influenced by progesterone
  • ➤ lactation postpartum.
